review.title: Maximin Safety: When Failing to Lose is Preferable to Trying to Win
review.abstract: We present a new decision rule, \emph{maximin safety}, that seeks to maintain a large margin from the worst outcome, in much the same way minimax regret seeks to minimize distance from the best. We argue that maximin safety is valuable both descriptively and normatively. Descriptively, maximin safety explains the well-known \emph{decoy effect}, in which the introduction of a dominated option changes preferences among the other options. Normatively, we provide an axiomatization that characterizes preferences induced by maximin safety, and show that maximin safety shares much of the same behavioral basis with minimax regret.

We argue that Maximin Security is both descriptive and normative. Descriptively, maximin Security explains the well-known lure effect, in which the introduction of a dominated option changes preferences among the other options. Normally, we offer an axiomatization that characterizes preferences generated by maximum security, and show that Maximin Security shares much of the same behavioral basis with minimax remorse.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The representation of uncertainty by means of a probability distribution and the making of decisions by maximizing the expected benefits is widely accepted, based on formal mathematical principles, and satisfies intuitive notions of rationality such as the independence of irrelevant alternatives and the principle of safe acting [20]. However, the enforcement of seemingly appealing concepts of rationality can ultimately lead to decisions that are incompatible with what real people consider reasonable. For example, the observed behavior under unquantifiable (Knightian [14] / strict [15]) uncertainties, such as the one in the Ellsberg paradox [8], shows how appealing concepts of rationality can lead to inconsistencies with human decisions. Alternative decision rules, such as maximum usefulness [25] and minimax regret [20] provide rationally plausible decisions in ambiguous situations and can be used to resolve them.
